item.title: PCOS on a Budget
item.dc:creator: tpetts
item.content:encoded:
Chapter 1: Budget-Friendly Food That
Fuels Hormones


Because your ovaries don’t care if it came from Whole Foods or Walmart — they just want real nourishment.

The Myth: “Eating Healthy Is Too Expensive”


How many times have you thought:
“I’d eat healthier, but I can’t afford all that organic, gluten-free, dairy-free, keto whatever stuff.”


And yeah, if you’re shopping with a $16 smoothie recipe and a celebrity
wellness influencer’s pantry in mind, it will get pricey. But healing PCOS
isn’t about labels. It’s about strategy — and blood sugar balance.


Let’s break this down:


Balancing your hormones = balancing your blood sugar + reducing
inflammation + supporting digestion.

And you can do all of that with simple, low-cost, real food.

�� Budget Rule #1: Focus on Real Food Staples


You don’t need fancy ingredients. Start with whole foods you can repurpose
across multiple meals.


�� Hormone-Supportive Budget Staples:

Budget Rule #2: Build a PCOS Plate for $5 or Less

Every meal should aim for 3 key elements:

  •  ✅ Protein (eggs, chicken, lentils)
  •  ✅ Healthy fat (avocado, olive oil, seeds)
  •  ✅ Fiber-rich carb (sweet potatoes, quinoa, veggies)

Example: $4.85 Hormone-Loving Lunch

  •  ½ cup cooked quinoa
  •  1 cup sautéed kale + frozen peppers
  •  2 scrambled eggs
  •  Topped with olive oil + hemp seeds + lemon


Simple. Balanced. Zero blood sugar crash.

�� Budget Rule #3: Batch Cook Like a Hormone Boss

Cooking a few things once can save you $ and mental energy all week.
Here’s a cheap & easy lineup to prep on Sundays:

  •  �� Roasted sweet potatoes
  •  �� Hard-boiled eggs
  •  �� One big hormone-friendly curry or chili (use lentils, beans, or ground turkey)
  •  �� Chopped raw veg for snacking
  •  �� A grain: brown rice, quinoa, or oats
  • ✨ One batch of Jay’s Seed & Slay Balls (because snacks are self-care)

➡ Use these as mix-and-match building blocks for breakfast bowls, quick lunches, and no-fuss dinners.

��‍♀️ Smart Budget Tips for Grocery Shopping:

  •  �� Shop the sales FIRST — then build your meal plan around what’s affordable
  •  �� Frozen is your friend — frozen berries, greens, cauliflower rice = nutrient-packed & cost-effective
  •  �� Bulk bins > pre-packaged — buy seeds, spices, and oats this way to save major cash
  •  �� Store brands over name brands — always
  •  �� Skip “health halos” — gluten-free cookies and $12 granola aren’t health foods, they’re marketing

5 Budget-Friendly Hormone-Loving Meals

  1. Chickpea Sweet Potato Stew
     Canned chickpeas + onion + garlic + sweet potatoes + turmeric
     Simmer with veggie broth + coconut milk
  2. Egg + Veggie Power Bowl
     Scrambled eggs + sautéed spinach + brown rice + tahini drizzle
  3. Tuna Salad Wraps
     Canned tuna + avocado + lemon + mustard + chopped celery in
    lettuce leaves
  4. One-Pot Turkey + Lentil Chili

 Ground turkey + canned lentils + tomatoes + bell peppers + spices

  1. Overnight Oats (Hormone Edition)
     Oats + almond milk + flax seeds + cinnamon + frozen berries + scoop of protein powder

�� Real Talk: You Don’t Need to Be Perfect — You Just Need to Be Consistent

You’re not failing because you didn’t buy organic.
You’re not behind because you’re making meals with $1.99 beans instead of bison liver and sea moss.
You’re resourceful. You’re learning. You’re supporting your hormones with what you’ve got — and that’s powerful AF.

�� Chapter 2: Supplements on a Shoestring

Because not every “hormone hack” needs to cost $79.99 a bottle.

�� First: Do You Need Supplements?


Short answer? Not always.

But can the right ones support your healing? Absolutely.
The catch? You don’t need the “influencer shelf” — you need the
essentials, based on what your body actually needs. Supplements
should supplement a balanced foundation — not replace food, sleep, or
stress care.

So let’s get into how to do this smart and on a budget.

✅ Start with the Foundational 5

If you’re only going to spend money on a few things — these are the ones that make the most bang-for-your-buck impact for PCOS:

  1. Magnesium (glycinate or citrate)
    �� Helps with: insulin resistance, sleep, mood, cravings, PMS
    �� Affordable brands: NOW, Pure Encapsulations
    �� Dosage: 300–400mg at night
    ✨ Bonus: You’ll probably poop better too.
  2. Vitamin D3 + K2
    • �� Helps with: ovulation, immune regulation, hormone signaling
    • �� Tip: Get your levels tested — most PCOS babes are low
    • �� Dosage: 2,000–5,000 IU daily with food + fat
    • �� If you’re on a tight budget — sunshine is free. 15–20 minutes a day = magic.
  3. Omega-3 (EPA/DHA)
    �� Helps with: inflammation, egg quality, hormone production, period pain
    �� Budget buy: Costco’s fish oil, or Barlean’s Omega Swirl (on sale!)
    �� Dosage: 1,000–2,000 mg combined EPA/DHA
    �� Can’t afford a supplement? Eat canned wild salmon or sardines 2x/week.
  4. Inositol (Myo or Myo + D-Chiro Blend)
    �� Helps with: insulin resistance, ovulation, egg quality
    �� Budget brands: Wholesome Story (Amazon), BulkSupplements
    �� Dosage: Myo-inositol 2g twice daily (or combo blend 40:1 ratio)
    �� Especially helpful if you have irregular periods or PCOS-related
    infertility.
  5. A Quality Multivitamin or Prenatal
    �� Helps with: filling nutritional gaps when food isn’t perfect
    �� Look for: methylated B vitamins (folate > folic acid), no fillers
    �� Brands under $30: Naturelo, SmartyPants, Seeking Health (often on
    sale)
    �� Skip anything that says “One-A-Day” — it’s underdosed and overhyped.

❌ What You Can (Probably) Skip

Unless your practitioner specifically tells you to, you don’t need to drop $$$ on:
 Supergreens powders
 Collagen peptides (nice, not necessary)
 DIM or estrogen blockers (can be too strong for self-dosing)
 Berberine (unless you’re under supervision — it’s potent)
 Random hormone balancers with 15+ mystery herbs
✨ Reminder: More is not better. Targeted > trendy.

��️ Where to Buy Supplements Without Spending a Fortune

�� The $50 Starter Stack (For Real Ones on a Budget)


Here’s what to grab if you’re just starting out and want maximum impact
with minimal spend:

�� Total = ~$50 or less if you catch a sale
�� Pair this with food-first healing, and you’re golden.

�� Real Talk: If You Can’t Afford Supplements Right Now…

You’re not behind.
You’re not failing.
You’re still healing — because food, movement, and nervous system
regulation are free tools that WORK.

Focus on what you can do:
 Get outside.
 Eat protein every meal.
 Walk after you eat.
 Sleep 7+ hours.
 Support your gut with whole foods and herbs.

Supplements help, but you are the real medicine.

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

��‍♀️ Chapter 3: Free (or Almost Free) Healing Practices


Because some of the best PCOS treatments don’t come in a bottle — they come in the form of consistency, calm, and conscious care.

✨ The Truth: You Don’t Have to Buy Your Way to Healing


Some of the most effective tools for PCOS support are things that don’t
cost anything — they just require your time, your awareness, and your
willingness to slow down.

We’ve been taught that healing comes in fancy packaging or with a high
price tag. But here’s what I want you to remember:


The things that move the needle the most — like blood sugar balance,
stress support, and movement — are usually free.


So let’s break down the top habits that support hormone healing without draining your bank account.

��‍♀️ 1. Walking (Seriously. Just Walk.)
Forget bootcamp. Forget $180/month gyms.
Walking is one of the BEST forms of movement for PCOS.
Why it works:
 Supports insulin sensitivity
 Lowers cortisol
 Reduces inflammation
 Improves digestion and lymphatic flow
 Helps regulate appetite and mood
�� Try:

 A 10-minute walk after meals = blood sugar GOLD
 20–30 minutes a day of steady, joyful movement (not punishment)
 Walk while you listen to a podcast, music, or complete silence —
whatever feeds your nervous system

��‍♀️ 2. Nervous System Regulation
PCOS isn’t just a hormone thing — it’s a stress thing.
When your body is constantly in “fight or flight,” it’s going to deprioritize
things like ovulation, digestion, and hormone balance.
So we have to tell your nervous system: you’re safe now.


Free Tools That Help:
 ✨ Box Breathing: Inhale 4, hold 4, exhale 4, hold 4
 ✨ Cold Water Splash: On your face for vagus nerve activation
 ✨ Humming/Singing: Yep, activates your vagus nerve
 ✨ Grounding: Stand barefoot outside for 5–10 minutes
 ✨ Journaling: Release what you’re holding, daily or as needed


You don’t need a meditation app. You need a quiet moment to check in with your body. That’s free.

�� 3. DIY Seed Cycling (Under $5 a Month)
Seed cycling is a gentle way to support estrogen and progesterone
throughout your cycle using real food.


How to Do It:
 Days 1–14 (Follicular phase): 1 tbsp flax + 1 tbsp pumpkin seeds
daily
 Days 15–28 (Luteal phase): 1 tbsp sunflower + 1 tbsp sesame
seeds daily


�� Buy in bulk, grind fresh if possible, store in the fridge.

Mix them into:
 Smoothies
 Oatmeal
 Yogurt bowls
 Chia pudding
 Jay’s Seed & Slay Balls ��

�� 4. Herbal Teas: A Budget-Friendly Wellness Hack
Teas are a super affordable way to bring in hormone support, digestive
support, and stress reduction.


Tea Faves by Goal:

✨ Most bulk teas cost less than $6 and last weeks.

��‍♂️ 5. Free or Low-Cost Movement
If you can’t afford a gym, that’s not a problem. YouTube is overflowing with free movement options that are PCOS-friendly.


Try:
 Yoga with Adriene (YouTube)
 Melissa Wood Health ($10/month if you want a low-cost gentle
option)

 Dance parties in your kitchen
 10-minute stretch flows
 Bodyweight circuits at home


Remember: you’re moving to feel better, not burn calories.

�� 6. Track Your Cycle for Free
Understanding your cycle is essential with PCOS — especially because it can be irregular. And while fancy hormone trackers exist, you can start with free apps or a printable calendar.


Free Tools:
 Clue or Flo app (free versions)
 Paper tracker (bonus: mindful connection)
 Free basal body temp tracking sheets
 Cervical mucus notes in your journal or app
�� Track for at least 2–3 months to start seeing your patterns.

�� Final Word: This Chapter Isn’t “Extra” — It’s the Foundation
If you’re doing none of these things and only taking supplements? You’ll
probably feel frustrated.
If you’re doing just these things without any supplements? You’ll still make progress.
These tools are about creating a healing environment — a body that feels safe, supported, and ready to rebalance.
And the price tag? $0–$5.


Can’t beat that.

�� Chapter 4: Grocery Shopping Like a PCOS Girl Boss

Because you don’t need a Whole Foods haul to eat like a hormone-healing queen.

�� The Vibe: Strategy > Stress


If the idea of grocery shopping for your hormones makes your eyes glaze over, trust me — I get it. Between reading labels, decoding what’s “healthy,” and trying not to spend your rent money in one aisle, it can feel overwhelming.


So let’s simplify this. Shopping for PCOS doesn’t mean a cart full of kale
and kombucha. It means stocking up on real food that works for your
body — and stretching that food across the week like the resourceful
goddess you are.

�� Step 1: Know the Healing Goals
We’re not just shopping for random “healthy” stuff. We’re shopping for
foods that support:
 ✅ Blood sugar balance
 ✅ Gut health
 ✅ Inflammation reduction
 ✅ Hormone production + detox
 ✅ Ovulation support
…and we’re doing it without $18 “superfoods” or protein powders that taste like wet cardboard.

�� Step 2: Shop by Category (Not by Trend)

Here’s your core PCOS-friendly grocery list — simple, affordable, and
easy to customize based on sales and your taste buds.


�� Produce
(fresh or frozen — frozen is often cheaper and just as nutrient-rich)
 Spinach, kale, arugula
 Broccoli, cauliflower, cabbage
 Carrots, sweet potatoes, beets
 Zucchini, bell peppers, onions
 Lemons, limes, garlic, ginger
 Berries (frozen = budget-friendly magic)
 Bananas (green or slightly underripe for gut health)
�� Proteins
 Pasture-raised eggs (or whatever you can afford)
 Ground turkey or chicken thighs
 Canned wild salmon, sardines, or tuna
 Canned beans (chickpeas, black beans, lentils)
 Greek yogurt (plain, full-fat)
 Protein powder (optional — go budget if you use it)
�� Healthy Fats
 Olive oil or avocado oil
 Nut butters (almond, sunflower seed, peanut)
 Coconut oil
 Chia, flax, pumpkin, and sunflower seeds
 Avocados (yes, get the bagged ones)
�� Smart Carbs + Fiber
 Brown rice or quinoa
 Gluten-free oats
 Lentils and black beans
 Cassava or almond flour (optional baking staples)
 Sweet potatoes, squash, carrots


�� Extras That Matter

 Apple cider vinegar
 Nutritional yeast (B vitamin love)
 Herbal teas (peppermint, ginger, raspberry leaf)
 Coconut aminos (soy sauce alternative)
 Spices: turmeric, cinnamon, cumin, garlic powder

�� Step 3: Budget Boss Tips (So You Don’t Overspend)

  1. Shop the sales, not the trends.
    o Base your meals around what’s affordable that week — not
    what your feed says is “in.”
  2. Choose frozen or canned over fresh when needed.
    o Frozen spinach, berries, cauliflower rice = budget GOLD.
  3. Skip the “health halo” snacks.
    o $7 kale chips or gluten-free cookies are still processed food.
    You can DIY snacks for half the price.
  4. Pick 2–3 core meals to rotate.
    o This cuts down on food waste, decision fatigue, and cost.
  5. Buy in bulk — but only for things you actually use.
    o Seeds, oats, lentils, and spices? Yes.
    o Random almond flour crackers? Probably not.

�� Step 4: Create a “Remixable” Grocery Plan


Here’s how to stretch your grocery haul into a full week:
Meal Base #1: Sweet potatoes + turkey + greens
 Remix as: bowls, hashes, taco filling, or salad topper
Meal Base #2: Quinoa + canned beans + veggies
 Remix as: stir-fry, burrito bowl, warm salad, soup base
Meal Base #3: Eggs + greens + whatever’s leftover

 Remix as: frittatas, breakfast burritos, scrambles

Snack Base:
 Apple + nut butter
 Yogurt + flax + berries
 Seed & Slay balls
 Veggies + hummus
 Chia pudding
✨ You don’t need 21 different meals for 7 days. You need a few solid
combos you actually like.

�� Pro Tip: Read Labels Without Getting a Headache


Keep it simple:
 Look for ingredients you can pronounce
 Skip products with added sugars, “vegetable oils,” or mystery
flavorings
 Aim for 5 ingredients or fewer in packaged foods
If the ingredient list looks like a science experiment, put it back, bestie.

�� Final Word: This Is About Progress, Not Perfection
Some weeks you’ll get the organic pasture-raised everything. Some weeks
you’ll be grabbing canned beans and frozen spinach on sale.
Both are valid. Both are healing. Both are part of your journey.
What matters most is showing up for yourself with the resources you do
have — not the ones you wish you had.

❤️ Chapter 5: What Healing Really Looks Like (On a Budget or Not)


Because healing isn’t linear, aesthetic, or always Instagrammable — but it’s worth every messy, magical step.

�� First Things First: Healing ≠ Perfection
There’s a version of “healing” floating around social media that’s all yoga
mats, green smoothies, and $100 lymphatic brushes.


Here’s the real version:
 Sometimes healing is eating the eggs you can afford, not organic
pastured ones.
 Sometimes it’s skipping the workout because you chose sleep.
 Sometimes it’s crying on the kitchen floor because your period
showed up again — but getting up anyway.
Healing isn’t perfect. It’s persistent.
And you are doing better than you think.

�� What Healing Actually Looks Like Over Time
Let’s get real about what to expect — not just physically, but emotionally.

Healing is not linear. There will be flare-ups, fatigue, frustration. But there will also be breakthroughs. Lightness. And moments where you realize:
“Oh. I feel like me again.”

��️ Tracking Progress (Without Obsessing)


You don’t need to weigh yourself every week or track macros like a
spreadsheet. You do need ways to measure how your body is responding.


Try tracking:
 �� Period frequency, flow, and symptoms
 ��️ Ovulation signs (mucus, LH strips, BBT)
 �� Energy, mood, and sleep
 �� Cravings and digestion
 �� What’s getting easier (stairs? sleep? saying no?)

You can use a cycle tracking app or just jot it down in a notebook. Make it simple. Make it honest.

�� Body Love While You Heal


This one’s important: You are allowed to love your body while still
working on it.

PCOS can mess with your confidence. Hair where you don’t want it,
periods that ghost you, weight that won’t budge — it’s a lot.

But your body is not your enemy.
It’s not failing you.
It’s speaking to you.

What you may see as symptoms are actually signs — and you’re learning how to read them. That’s powerful.

Start with:
 Wearing clothes that make you feel good now
 Nourishing your body with kindness, not punishment
 Saying “thank you” for what your body can do today
You’re healing a relationship — not just with your hormones, but with
yourself.

�� Building a Support Squad (On the Cheap)

You don’t need a full wellness team. But you do need support.

Free or low-cost ways to get it:
 ✅ Join online PCOS communities or subreddits
 ✅ Follow educators who teach, not just sell
 ✅ Ask your doctor for sliding scale labs or referrals
 ✅ Use community health centers for check-ins
 ✅ Create a healing buddy system — cook or check in weekly with a
friend

You’re not meant to heal alone.

�� Final Words: You’re Not Just Healing — You’re Reclaiming


This guide wasn’t about quick fixes. It was about reclaiming power in a
world that’s made PCOS feel like a mystery wrapped in shame and marked “expensive.”

You’ve learned how to:
 Eat for your hormones without going broke
 Supplement strategically
 Use free tools that support your whole body
 Grocery shop like a PCOS girl boss
 Track your progress and celebrate every win

You’ve got this. Even on hard days. Especially on hard days.
Healing isn’t about doing it all.
It’s about doing what you can do with what you have — and believing that it’s enough.


And sis… it is.

You are.


��️ 7-Day Cheap & Chic PCOS Meal Plan

Simple, satisfying meals to nourish your hormones without wrecking your wallet.
"No gluten, no dairy, no overpriced snacks — just real food, smart combos, and budget boss vibes."

�� DAY 1


Breakfast: Scrambled eggs with sautéed spinach + sweet potato hash
Snack: Apple slices with sunflower seed butter
Lunch: Chickpea + veggie stir-fry over brown rice
Snack: Chia pudding (made with almond milk + flax)
Dinner: Turkey & black bean chili (make enough for leftovers!)

�� Prep tip: Cook a big batch of rice and chili for Days 2–3.

�� DAY 2


Breakfast: Overnight oats with frozen berries, flaxseed & cinnamon
Snack: Hard-boiled egg + cucumber slices
Lunch: Leftover turkey chili + quinoa or brown rice
Snack: Carrot sticks + hummus
Dinner: Garlic roasted sweet potatoes + steamed broccoli + a fried egg

�� Hack: Roast extra sweet potatoes + broccoli for future dinners.

�� DAY 3


Breakfast: Chia pudding topped with banana + cinnamon
Snack: Jay’s Seed & Slay Ball (or DIY version!)
Lunch: Tuna salad lettuce wraps + leftover sweet potatoes
Snack: Unsweetened yogurt + flax + cinnamon
Dinner: Lentil curry with canned lentils, tomato, garlic, and frozen veggies


�� $ saver: Canned lentils + frozen veg = $2 meal win.

�� DAY 4

Breakfast: Protein smoothie (banana, flax, oats, cinnamon, protein powder
or egg whites)
Snack: Celery + sunflower seed butter
Lunch: Quinoa + roasted veggies + tahini drizzle
Snack: Popcorn with olive oil + sea salt
Dinner: Scrambled eggs + sautéed kale + avocado (breakfast for dinner)


�� Budget bonus: Eggs = one of the cheapest high-quality proteins.

�� DAY 5


Breakfast: Overnight oats with chia, almond butter + cinnamon
Snack: Hard-boiled egg + carrot sticks
Lunch: Lentil salad with cucumbers, olive oil + lemon (use leftovers!)
Snack: Apple + tahini
Dinner: Chickpea sweet potato stew with garlic, onion, and turmeric


�� Cook once, eat twice: Stew can stretch to lunch on Day 6.

�� DAY 6


Breakfast: Fried eggs + roasted sweet potatoes + greens
Snack: Yogurt with cinnamon + chia

Lunch: Leftover chickpea stew or a simple veggie wrap
Snack: Banana + almond butter
Dinner: Zucchini stir fry with rice + scrambled egg + tamari

�� Budget spice swap: Use coconut aminos or low-sodium soy sauce.

�� DAY 7

Breakfast: Smoothie bowl (frozen berries, banana, chia, water) + seed
topping
Snack: Rice cake + sunflower seed butter
Lunch: Sweet potato & lentil mash + greens
Snack: Jay’s Seed & Slay Ball
Dinner: Sheet pan dinner: roasted carrots, broccoli, onion + baked egg or
canned salmon


�� Closeout tip: Use up all leftover veg in the sheet pan meal!

��️ Budget Grocery Staples Used:
 Eggs
 Ground turkey (or canned tuna)
 Canned beans (chickpeas, black beans, lentils)
 Sweet potatoes, carrots, onions
 Frozen spinach or broccoli
 Brown rice, oats, quinoa
 Flax, chia, cinnamon
 Olive oil, tahini or seed butter
 Bananas, apples, lemons
 Almond milk or unsweetened plant milk
 Garlic, cumin, turmeric, sea salt


Jay's Seed & Slay Balls™ - Craving Control Kit

Snack your way through your cycle with Jay's Seed & Slay Balls™.
These phase-based hormone bites are crafted to satisfy cravings
while nourishing your body with the ingredients it actually needs.

Each recipe supports your hormones, blood sugar, mood, and
cravings — naturally.

 ✨ Follicular Phase: Glowballs


 Ingredients:

  • 1/2 cup ground flaxseed
  • 1/2 cup ground pumpkin seeds
  • 1/4 cup almond butter
  • 1 tbsp coconut oil
  • 1 tsp maca powder
  • 1/4 tsp cinnamon
  • Zest of 1 lemon
  • Optional: 1 tbsp freeze-dried raspberries or bee pollen
  • Optional: 1–2 tsp maple syrup or date syrup
     Instructions:
    Mix all ingredients in a bowl until well combined. Roll into small bite-
    sized balls. Store in the fridge for up to 1 week or freeze for up to 1
    month.
  •  �� Luteal Phase: Calm & Collected Balls
     Ingredients:
  • 1/2 cup ground sunflower seeds
  • 1/2 cup ground sesame seeds
  • 1/4 cup sunflower seed butter
  • 1 tbsp coconut oil
  • 1 tbsp raw cacao powder
  • 1/2 tsp vanilla extract
  • Pinch of sea salt
  • Optional: 1–2 chopped medjool dates or 1 tbsp chopped figs
  • Optional: cacao nibs for crunch
     Instructions:
    Combine all ingredients in a bowl. Mix well, roll into balls, and chill.
    Store in the fridge or freezer and enjoy 1–2 daily based on your cycle
    phase.

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

Let's access your first mini-class!

This guide is your roadmap for smart, affordable, real-life hormone healing.
We’ll cover:

  • How to grocery shop like a PCOS queen without the Whole Foods price tag
  • The supplements that actually matter — and the ones you can skip
  • Free healing habits that support your hormones, gut, and mood
  • A sample PCOS-friendly meal plan that won’t break the bank
  • A breakdown of what healing really looks like when you're doing it on a budget

This isn’t a detox. This isn’t a diet. This is a realistic path to balance for women who are tired of being tired — and tired of being told it’s all in their head.


You don’t need to be perfect. You don’t need to be rich.

You just need to be ready.


Ready to eat better without the overwhelm.
Ready to listen to your body without the judgment.
Ready to show up — for your healing, for your hormones, and for yourself.


Let’s get into it.

Log in

🏡 House of Jay Terms and Conditions + Disclaimer

Effective Date: 04/27/2025

1. Acceptance of Terms

By accessing, browsing, or using this website, its courses, downloads, coaching services, or any associated materials (collectively “Services”), you agree to be bound by these Terms and Conditions. If you do not agree to these terms, please do not use the Services.

2. Educational and Informational Purposes Only

All content provided by House of Jay, including but not limited to coaching programs, guides, blog posts, videos, handouts, and downloads, is intended for educational and informational purposes only.

Nothing on this site or provided through these Services should be considered or construed as medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment.
You are encouraged to consult your physician or other qualified healthcare provider before beginning any wellness, nutrition, or lifestyle program.

3. No Client-Practitioner Relationship

Participation in House of Jay Services, including but not limited to courses, free content, or newsletter subscriptions, does not automatically create a client-practitioner relationship.

A client relationship is only established through a separate formal agreement after completion of the Premier Case Review and signing of a Coaching Agreement.

4. Personal Responsibility

You acknowledge that you are voluntarily participating in the Services and that you are solely and personally responsible for your choices, actions, and results.

You agree to use your own judgment and conduct due diligence before applying any information provided through House of Jay Services.

5. Intellectual Property

All materials provided through House of Jay are protected by copyright, trademark, and other intellectual property laws.

Unless explicitly authorized, you may not reproduce, modify, sell, share, publish, or distribute any materials from House of Jay without prior written permission.

6. No Guarantees

House of Jay makes no guarantees about specific results you may experience from using the Services.

Each individual’s health journey is unique, and outcomes depend on a wide variety of personal factors beyond the scope of House of Jay's knowledge or control.

7. Limitation of Liability

To the fullest extent permitted by law, House of Jay, including Jacquelyn Fryndej-Cruz and any employees, contractors, or affiliates, shall not be liable for any direct, indirect, incidental, consequential, or special damages arising from your use of the Services.

You agree to indemnify and hold harmless House of Jay and Jacquelyn Fryndej-Cruz from any claims arising out of your participation or use of the Services.

8. Affiliate Links and Sponsored Content

Some blog posts, emails, or materials may contain affiliate links or mentions of products.
House of Jay may earn a small commission at no additional cost to you if you make a purchase through these links.
Any sponsored content will be clearly identified.

9. Privacy

Any personal information you provide to House of Jay is subject to our Privacy Policy, which outlines how we collect, use, and safeguard your data.

10. Changes to Terms

House of Jay reserves the right to update or change these Terms and Conditions at any time.
Continued use of the Services after such changes constitutes your acceptance of the new Terms.

🛡️ Disclaimer (Highlighted)

Disclaimer:
The information provided by House of Jay, Jacquelyn Fryndej-Cruz, and affiliated materials is for educational purposes only and is not intended to diagnose, treat, cure, or prevent any disease.

Participation in House of Jay Services does not replace individualized medical advice or care from your personal physician or healthcare provider.
You should always consult with a qualified medical professional before making any health-related decisions.

House of Jay Services are not intended for individuals under the age of 18 without parental or guardian consent.

By using this site and engaging with our materials, you acknowledge and agree to this Disclaimer.

item.title: “It’s Just Bloating” — and Other Lies We’ve Been Told
item.dc:creator: jfrycruz
item.content:encoded:
Let’s talk about the belly.
Not the cute, “I just ate a burrito” belly.
I mean the tight, uncomfortable, gassy, “why do I look 6 months pregnant at 3 PM” kind of belly.
You know the one.
Maybe it’s there in the afternoon, after what seemed like a “healthy” lunch.
Maybe it flares with stress.
Maybe it doesn’t make sense at all — and that’s the part that’s messing with your head.
If you’ve ever been told that bloating is:
• “Normal”
• “Just what happens when you eat”
• “Fixed with peppermint tea or probiotics”
...this one’s for you.
________________________________________
🧠 First Things First: What Is Bloating Really?
Bloating isn’t just about having gas or being “too full.”
Bloating is a symptom — a signal from your body saying:
“Hey, something’s not right here. I’m trying to deal with it, but I need some help.”
In functional nutrition, we don’t just ask how to get rid of it — we ask:
• Where is it coming from?
• What system is out of balance?
• What else is showing up alongside it?
Because bloating is rarely alone. It often hangs out with:
• Fatigue
• Constipation or loose stools
• Brain fog
• Hormonal imbalances
• Anxiety or stress flare-ups
• Skin issues or headaches
________________________________________
❌ Myth #1: “Bloating Is Normal After Meals”
🧍🏽‍♀️ Truth: A little post-meal fullness is expected — but bloating that makes you need stretchy pants or makes you feel 6-months-pregnant by 2 PM? Not normal.
That’s a red flag for:
• Low stomach acid
• Slow digestion
• Food sensitivities
• Gut dysbiosis
• Imbalanced blood sugar
Your digestive system should break food down smoothly. If it’s not, bloating is your flare gun.
________________________________________
❌ Myth #2: “You Just Need to Drink More Water”
🚰 Truth: Yes, dehydration can make bloating worse.
But if you’re pounding water all day and still bloated, we need to look deeper.
Functional reasons could include:
• You’re not absorbing your water (electrolytes matter)
• You’re constipated and water’s not moving through
• You’re bloated from gut inflammation or imbalance — and extra water is just adding volume to a system that’s already stuck
________________________________________
❌ Myth #3: “It’s Just Fiber — Your Gut Will Get Used to It”
🥦 Truth: Fiber can help — but it can also make things worse if your gut isn’t ready.
If you have bloating after eating veggies, beans, or whole grains, you might have:
• Low digestive enzyme output
• SIBO (small intestinal bacterial overgrowth)
• An inflamed or overly sensitive gut lining
We don’t force-feed fiber to a gut that’s already freaking out. We gently support digestion first — with enzymes, cooked foods, and a slower ramp-up.
________________________________________
❌ Myth #4: “Take a Probiotic and You'll Be Fine”
💊 Truth: Probiotics are not a one-size-fits-all solution.
Some people actually get more bloated on the wrong probiotic — especially with SIBO or histamine intolerance.
Before adding supplements, ask:
• What’s the current state of my gut flora?
• Am I feeding the good bugs with real food?
• Do I need to reduce inflammation first?
Sometimes the best probiotic is a calming meal and a deep breath.
________________________________________
✅ So… What Does Help?
Here’s what we do From the Nest:
• Slow down your meals. Digestion starts in the mouth — chew, breathe, don’t rush.
• Start with cooked foods. Raw can be hard on a sensitive gut.
• Support your enzymes. A little apple cider vinegar or bitters pre-meal can help.
• Identify trigger patterns. (Are you always bloated after eggs? After stress? After dinner?)
• Balance your blood sugar. Yep — your gut and your glucose are on the same team.
And above all: Listen to your body — not the TikTok “wellness” girlies who tell you bloating is sexy and normal. 🙃
________________________________________
💛 Final Thought:
Bloating is a messenger — not a life sentence.
If it’s showing up every day, you don’t need to mask it.
You need someone to help you understand it.
And that’s what I’m here for.
So if you’re bloated, frustrated, and tired of guessing — see things From the Nest. You’re not crazy. You’re not broken.
You just need a new way to listen.
Until next time,
Jay 🐦
